utterances.sentences: No, I don't think we're going to do that.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: You seem very relaxed. How do you say so chill in New York City?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: A lot of wine. I'm just kidding.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: That's what I do. What have you done that's been so relaxing?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: We took the ferry to Staten Island.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: The Staten Island ferry is relaxing. This is all very incredible information.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: It's actually pretty stressful. It's a really big cultural shock. Very different from anything I'm used to seeing.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: You came from New York City from Spain for a vacation. Do you feel relaxed right now?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Sometimes I just, you know, stay under my bed, and you know, just stay there and I don't leave. I never felt like the words "vacation" and "New York City" belonged in the same sentence.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: I'm a big theater nerd. So, like, this is where the best theater is. So for me, like, doing that and seeing something new is a vacation.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Wow, that's like -- I do see something new every day here. Not always good stuff, though. You look very relaxed right now. Are you relaxing in New York?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: That's a very relaxed answer. He didn't even care I was asking the question. That's amazing. I need more of this attitude. Can we talk later?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: We go, like, rat watching in the subway system.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: You go rat watching in the subways?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Yes, we do.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: So I should be looking at the rats as my friends/a potential evening plan. So maybe New York is kind of awesome. I just need to embrace it. Also, if anybody wants to go rat watching with me in the subway later, I'd be willing to give it a try.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Any takers? Rat watching?

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: No. Apparently, it's very common, though. Look, Times Square is iconic. People come to see all the lights and everything. And Broadway, that young lady said she comes to Broadway.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: It's the best Broadway -- it's the best theater on the planet. But did you ever notice, like, all these post-apocalyptic movies, like, the world is ending, Times Square is still kicking?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Like, everyone meets in Times Square and they survive?

utterances.speaker: ELLEITHEE
utterances.sentences: They could make a (UNINTELLIGIBLE) of tourism, right?

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: ELLEITHEE
utterances.sentences: Look, the most stressful thing about -- I live in D.C. Not exactly the most relaxed city in the world.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: ELLEITHEE
utterances.sentences: The most stressful thing about New York is getting here for me. To the powers that be, if you can fix LaGuardia Airport, please! Do that! Right? But you know, look, I love this piece. I love these real Americans from all over the country, from all over the world, who just are excited to, like, be in New York and -- you come here to see things you will not see anywhere else.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: That is true. You want to weigh in?

utterances.speaker: KUCINICH
utterances.sentences: Look, I'm from Cleveland.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: KUCINICH
utterances.sentences: And next to Cleveland, New York is the greatest.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Cleveland is wonderful!

utterances.speaker: H. COOPER
utterances.sentences: I call that damning but faint praise.

utterances.speaker: KUCINICH
utterances.sentences: Oh, no, no, no. Cleveland is the greatest. But here...

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Not in baseball, though.

utterances.speaker: KUCINICH
utterances.sentences: Hey!

utterances.speaker: H. COOPER
utterances.sentences: Oh!

utterances.speaker: KUCINICH
utterances.sentences: First in American League and first in the hearts of the people. But energy, drama, excitement in the streets here. This -- there's a pulsation here. This town is alive! And so you've got to celebrate it.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: I agree. I love living here. It's very alive, very awake. But sometimes I want to take a nap. You know what I mean.

utterances.speaker: KUCINICH
utterances.sentences: Oh, come on.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: It's really, really hard.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Don't take one on the subway.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Yes, don't do that.

utterances.speaker: H. COOPER
utterances.sentences: Apparently not. According to what I've seen on "Drudge," it's not a good idea.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Not a good idea. Well, if New York stresses you out too much, Nevada could be your cup of tea to mellow out. Recreational weed because legal there two weeks ago. There's just one problem. Booming sales have now led to a statewide shortage. Stocks are so plum dry the state's Republican governor has been forced to step in and push emergency regulations to boost the number of distributors. You know, they're talking about million-dollar tax revenue here. Excuse me...

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Many, yes.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Yes, many millions, up to 100 million in tax revenue. So yes, they should probably get it together.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Listen, I'm on board. Legalize it, or definitely decriminalize it across the country and legalize it. The numbers you point out, massive tax revenue to the state, and they all need it.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Yes, absolutely.

utterances.speaker: H. COOPER
utterances.sentences: I'm not on board on the pot legalization train. You know, if Friday night comes along and you need something, what's wrong with a little Grey Goose that you can get at the corner? Why do you need to take this opportunity that really comes with a whole host of other baggage?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: I prefer vodka, personally. I would shoot -- yes, I'm not really a weed gal, but some people are; and that's their choice. And that should be their ability to get it legally if they want.

utterances.speaker: KUCINICH
utterances.sentences: I don't smoke. I don't drink. And I don't care if marijuana is legal.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KUCINICH
utterances.sentences: And if people can make revenue out of it, they did the same thing with alcohol.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: A hundred million is what they're saying in tax revenue, and why not? And if people, they can -- Nevada, they can probably get it anyways. They're just doing it legally, better, safer, tax revenue. Everybody is happy. Everybody should be a fan. All right. When he return -- I bet you some people won't be -- but we special back with our specialists, Dennis Kucinich and Horace Cooper. Come back.

utterances.speaker: ELLEITHEE
utterances.sentences: Time to "Circle Back" with our specialists, Dennis Kucinich and Horace Cooper. Congressman, you -- you're a Democrat. You were known to be a very liberal Democrat. But you recently slammed the Democratic Party for destroying the party as the party -- the opposition party, as effective opposition. What advice would you give to Democrats who want to make a contrast with this administration to be more effective?

utterances.speaker: KUCINICH
utterances.sentences: If you want to challenge Donald Trump, fine. But offer real alternatives. I think that, you know, the Democrats, in my view, shouldn't be locked into defending Obamacare but should be offering a real health care proposal: single-payer, Medicare for all. The Democrats ought to stand for peace, instead of voting for continually funding wars. The Democrats ought to stand for jobs for all. That goes in with Mr. Trump's infrastructure program. The Democrats ought to stand for education for all. There's 32 million Americans that are -- adults, who are -- who are illiterate. We've got to do something about lifting up the country.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Horace, my question is for you. You say you're a political forecaster. What's the political weather looks like next week? Heavy rain, Russia, what have we got?

utterances.speaker: H. COOPER
utterances.sentences: A Trump tweet.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: A Trump tweet, all right. That's probably 100 percent accurate.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Just a few more seconds right now. Go to my Twitter, take a look at the picture I posted of the congressman and I. We squared up. I said we're going to battle some liberals. You've got some good style; you've got some good form there, Congressman. A fighter?

utterances.speaker: KUCINICH
utterances.sentences: I am, a lot of practice. Actually, I'm a lover, not a fighter. I believe in peace, not war. And I love New York.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: He's a blackbelt. He told me. You said -- he said, "Legally, I have to warn you. I'm a black belt."

utterances.speaker: KUCINICH
utterances.sentences: No, no, I said martial artist. But that was...

utterances.speaker: H. COOPER
utterances.sentences: (UNINTELLIGIBLE) some jets there. But give war a chance!

utterances.speaker: KUCINICH
utterances.sentences: It's been given a chance.

utterances.speaker: ELLEITHEE
utterances.sentences: All right, thank you. Thank you to our "Fox News Specialists" today, Dennis Kucinich and Horace Cooper. And my thanks to everyone at Fox and "The Specialists" here for letting me sit in for Eboni K. Williams today. We thank you all for watching. Remember, 5 p.m. will never be the same. "Special Report" is next.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Weekend!

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Yes! Content and Programming Copyright 2017 Fox News Network, LLC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED. Copyright 2017 CQ-Roll Call, Inc. You may not alter or remove any trademark, copyright or other notice from copies of the content.

utterances.speaker: Wake Up, America
utterances.utterance: What happened to the tolerant left? This is a rush transcript from "The Fox News Specialists," July 14, 2017. This copy may not be in its final form and may be updated.

utterances.speaker: KATHERINE TIMPF, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Hello, everyone. I'm Kat Timpf along with Eric Bolling and Mo Elleithee who's filling in for Eboni K. Williams. We are "The Fox News Specialists." New names raising new questions about Donald Trump Jr. meeting with Russian lawyer Natalia Veselnitskaya. Fox News' John Roberts reporting a short time ago that there may have been at least eight people in attendance in that sit down. That includes a Russian-America lobbyist who reveals he's also attended the June 2016 meeting between the Russian lawyer, Trump, Jr., Jared Kushner, and Paul Manafort. The lobbyist, Rinat Akhmetshin, is a veteran of Soviet military counterintelligence unit. He has also reported ties to Russian intelligence, which is an accusation that he's denying, of course. Akhmetshin told the Associated Press today that the meeting was, quote, non-substantive, and he, quote, actually expected more serious discussion. Changing stories, raising issues for you, Eric, at all?

utterances.speaker: ERIC BOLLING, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: I'm sorry. I'm looking for the note where it says Trump, Jr., did anything wrong. No, I don't see anything in there that he did anything -- again, there were more people -- OK. So, I guess you could make the case that there are more people that he didn't mention before. But, I mean, honestly, it was a meeting, it was a sit down, it was portrayed as some opposition research, it ended up being something about an adoption policy program that we were -- that was being pulled, that these people were lobbying for. And at the end of the day, there's not much stand there for me still.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Why the changing stories, Mo? What do you think?

utterances.speaker: MO ELLEITHEE, GUEST HOST
utterances.utterance: That's my question.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: ELLEITHEE
utterances.utterance: Why all the changing stories. Look, there will be a robust discussion and debate, I'm sure, about whether or not this was collusion or not, whether it was wrong or not to take the meeting in the first place. I think it was. We can have an honest debate on that. But in the long time communication strategy.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: Would you think it was collusion?

utterances.speaker: ELLEITHEE
utterances.utterance: I think there's a lot of smoke here.

utterances.speaker: ELLEITHEE
utterances.utterance: Hold on, Eric. Look, my point is this, I think when a hostile foreign government comes in and says it wants to give you information against your opponent that should send up a lot of red flags.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: But he said.

utterances.speaker: ELLEITHEE
utterances.utterance: But, look, let me finish my other point. Let me finish my other point, which is for a White House that has been out there Trumpeting transparency around this whole thing because Donald, Jr. sent out the emails? Every day there is more to the story. As a communications strategist, I wonder what they're doing because it certainly does not put.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: I respect that part of it. But the part I'm pushing back on is - - you threw it right there right up the top, Mo. You said do you think there's collusion? I'm trying to find out who colluded to do what?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: And we've got a lot of time to talk about it, all right. But first, we got to meet the specialists. He's a Democratic former U.S. congressman from Ohio, he's also a former mayor of Cleveland, and he ran twice for president in 2004 and 2008, but he specializes in rescuing dogs and cats, so you know that he's a good guy, Dennis Kucinich is here. And he's a former law professor, the former deputy director of Voice of America, and the current co-chair of Project 21, an advocacy group for center-right African-Americans, but he specializes in the legal system and coalition building, Horace Cooper is here. We can all get involved in what I'm sure will be a very lively discussion. Horace, I just want to ask you. Does this raise any concerns to you that it keeps changing the story?

utterances.speaker: HORACE COOPER, FORMER LAW PROFESSOR
utterances.utterance: What raises concerns for me are the casually people use legal terms like claiming this treason, or collusion, etcetera, or that the Russian government did something. Last time I checked, if these were the 1950's, and you said because someone from the Soviet Union was involved in anything, that that was called redbaiting. It required you to actually identify what policy, what requirement, what expectation was being made by the official government of the former Soviet Union. Now we have people one of whom is a citizen of the United States now, because he was born in Russia, it's OK to just simply dismiss and washed all of his actions as if he's an agent of the country from which he was born. I used to think that was called un-American to do that on people based on where they were born.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: That, of course, is a separate issue. Specifically -- I'm not a lawyer. I don't pretend to be a lawyer. But as a human being if there's anybody that starts changing stories, I say, why are you doing that. Dennis, what do you think?

utterances.speaker: DENNIS KUCINICH, FORMER OHIO CONGRESSMAN
utterances.utterance: I'm not a lawyer, either. I just play one on TV.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Oh, OK.

utterances.speaker: KUCINICH
utterances.utterance: I was chairman of a congressional investigative subcommittee, so I get a feel for the flow of events and what people say. Here's where I read this. The Trump organization politically inexperience, so there may be inconsistencies in the stories. But when I look deeper at this meeting, let's say with his attorney, this attorney set the meeting under false pretenses. End up talking about anything relating to so-called dirt. And it turns out this person was also working to change some congressional legislation. So I look at that. And even more beyond that, what really blows my mind that it had a lot more has been made of it, this group that she was somehow connected with was doing opposition research on Donald Trump. So what is this? This is like a hall of mirrors. And big picture, I think this thing is a bunch of nothing. I really do.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: Can I follow up on the congressman? So this Fusion GPS is what we're talking about.

utterances.speaker: KUCINICH
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: Somehow connected through one of these people who are at the meeting, not sure which one, one of them -- so Natalia Veselnitskaya connected to Fusion GPS, who also was connected, Fusion GPS, to the opposition research -- the Russian dossier completely correct. Christopher Steele, the British operative who put together this Russian dossier somehow got payment from Fusion GPS. So, instead of pointing the finger at Donald Trump, Jr., saying maybe he's colluding -- Mo, big word, colluding with the Russians, maybe the Russians was colluding with Hillary Clinton. They had information on Donald Trump.

utterances.speaker: ELLEITHEE
utterances.utterance: Here's what concerns me, right. The one part of the sequence that's really concerning to me is where it said that this person has information that would damage your opponent. It is part of the Russian government's effort.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: All lies. All lies.

utterances.speaker: ELLEITHEE
utterances.utterance: But Donald Trump, Jr. did not know that before he walked into that meeting. He took the meeting. That should have sent up a red flag.

utterances.speaker: ELLEITHEE
utterances.utterance: The fact that this story keeps changing should send up another red flag.

utterances.speaker: KUCINICH
utterances.utterance: Mo, you know, I understand the concerns of expressed, but I'd like to go, you know, a little bit deeper. And that is that the log reads receiving something of value, he didn't receive anything of value. It was nothing. And whatever his intention was to get information. Look, I've been in politics a long time. People come to you and they say, hey, guess what I've got? If it's nothing, it's nothing. And nothing plus nothing equals nothing. And I don't think there is anything here. If I did, let me tell you, I wouldn't hesitate to say it. I've been a chairman of investigative subcommittee. I don't see it.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: Let me throw something else, Mo. So Veselnitskaya was originally turn down for a visa, and she reapplied through the -- so state department says no, but the DOJ, Loretta Lynch, says yes, we'll let you in. Why would the state department allow Veselnitskaya in when the state department said no? And then, also, know about this meeting. Now there's indication that the state department even knew this meeting was going to happen. There may have been a FISA court order.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Eric, I want to ask you. Do you think that this lawyer is dangerous or just a lawyer? Because I know you've said.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: Kat, after she left this meeting, she went to D.C. She's spent eight days in D.C. She was lobbying people in D.C., congress people. She showed up at a congressional testimony. She was knocking on doors for her.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: It was the adoption issue that she was consistent with. I think.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.utterance: So they did a bait and switch?

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.utterance: But let's go back to the 601 waiver, which you identified. This is an extraordinary issue and document. It isn't granted across the board. A high-level, doesn't have to be the attorney general, but a high-level individual approved this. And this is after she had been denied. And then, when you have this high-level approval, she's allowed to extend beyond its operational time point and nobody is watching her. But it's now Donald Trump, Jr.'s job to keep up with who she is and what she is doing? It would be.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: If she's dangerous. If she's dangerous it goes back to Obama's.

utterances.speaker: ELLEITHEE
utterances.utterance: What he knew was that someone with ties to the Russian government in an attempt to support his father's candidacy had information they wanted to share about Hillary Clinton. That, in and of itself, any other campaign operative I have ever met in my life, on either side of the aisle.

utterances.speaker: ELLEITHEE
utterances.utterance: Hold on. This is something worth.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: A very astute political advisor would say, hey, that's probably not politically expedient for you to do. Now, OK. I'll give you that. Certainly it wasn't illegal.

utterances.speaker: ELLEITHEE
utterances.utterance: It gets more than an issue of political expedience.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.utterance: I challenge the finding that he understood when he met with her that she had specific high-level ties with the Russian senior leadership. I challenge that.

utterances.speaker: ELLEITHEE
utterances.utterance: The email said it.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: The email said that.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.utterance: She's puffing.

utterances.speaker: ELLEITHEE
utterances.utterance: But he did not know that.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.utterance: But what he's trying to do is get the information. What he's trying to do is get the information. And as soon as he got into the meeting, he realized, you know what? I got duped. But you know what? I got duped last week on something else. And I got duped a week before on something else.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: And give him some credit. Maybe he's not been duped so much.

utterances.speaker: KUCINICH
utterances.utterance: It's a political inexperience here that reflects. And I think that Donald Trump, Jr. has learned a lesson, and I hope it's a valuable lesson. But, you know, right now, I'm trying to figure out if this story belongs on a Ludlum novel or it belongs to Mad Magazine? Five versus five, I don't know.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: The mainstream media loves this story. They're going wall to wall with it for the last -- just give me one shred of evidence. Give me one thing that he did or they did that breaks campaign finance law or breaks laws that govern everyone else.

utterances.speaker: ELLEITHEE
utterances.utterance: The email chain raises a whole lot of questions. That is legitimate for the investigation to look at.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: He hasn't broken any laws, though, Mo.

utterances.speaker: ELLEITHEE
utterances.utterance: I think the investigation will find that out. Maybe they will come to that conclusion, Eric. But, man, does it raise questions that are legitimate questions.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: Like what? Don't take opposition research from someone who says they have it?

utterances.speaker: ELLEITHEE
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: From a hostile force.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: Would you say the Ukrainian government would be equally as concerning to you as a political advisor.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Absolutely not.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: Why?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Ukraine and Russia, we have different relationships with those countries. I'm not defending that either. I think that was wrong. I think what the DNC did.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: I agree with you that what the DNC did in Ukraine was wrong. I completely agree with that. But if you think that's the same as what Donald Trump, Jr. did, then you'd think that what he did was wrong or you think the Ukraine was not wrong?

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: Hillary Clinton is far more in violation of everything we're about than what happened with Donald Trump Jr.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Why is that?

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: It's nothing.

utterances.speaker: KUCINICH
utterances.utterance: It's a nothing burger.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: But he wanted -- I mean, it was failed -- collusion, if used colloquially.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: I want all the money in the bank of New York, also. But I didn't go and steal it. And I'm not going to jail for wanting that either.

utterances.speaker: KUCINICH
utterances.utterance: We need to seriously work to improve our relationship with Russia.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Agree.

utterances.speaker: KUCINICH
utterances.utterance: We -- and we have to clear a way of all the dossiers, all of the fake issues, and get to real issues such as nuclear disarmament, environment, and other things. And we spent a lot of time on this and it's going nowhere. I don't care how many investigations they have. I've seen these kinds of investigations going nowhere.

utterances.speaker: ELLEITHEE
utterances.utterance: And I guess I would disagree with you, congressman, in that I don't think serious allegations about the Russian government trying -- whether or not they were successful, trying to meddle in our electoral process is a serious issue.

utterances.speaker: KUCINICH
utterances.utterance: I don't know if they have done that.

utterances.speaker: KUCINICH
utterances.utterance: Mo, it hasn't been proven that Donald Trump.

utterances.speaker: ELLEITHEE
utterances.utterance: What this special investigation is like.

utterances.speaker: ELLEITHEE
utterances.utterance: . and multiple intelligence agencies have said yes.

utterances.speaker: KUCINICH
utterances.utterance: Well, yeah. I mean, who knows if that's the political statement or a forensic statement. I mean, really.

utterances.speaker: ELLEITHEE
utterances.utterance: You know, I think we've all be giving U.S. intelligence agencies some credit here, as oppose to the Kremlin's mouthpieces.

utterances.speaker: KUCINICH
utterances.utterance: Well, this happened during a previous administration. It's political.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: All right. President Trump, in other news, health care is still a thing, guys. President Trump is turning up the heat on senate Republicans to get their health care bill over the line. Will moderates seal its fate? The latest, next.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: President Trump dialing up the pressure on senate Republicans to repeal and replace Obamacare. The president tweeting earlier today, quote, Republican senators are working hard to get their failed Obamacare replacement approved, I will be at my desk, pen in hand. The president also tweeting, quote, after all of these years of suffering through Obamacare, Republican senators must come through as they have promised. But a number of centrist Republicans are now reportedly digging in their heels demanding better funding for Medicaid and helping poor Americans by health insurance. So I'll bring it around, Horace. Let's start with you. Your thoughts on whether or not this bill has a chance of becoming a law?

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.utterance: I'm actually -- I'm kind of pessimistic. I know that the senate majority leader is the kind of guy that can pull a rabbit out of the hat. But I think this is a lot harder than even he and with the skills that he brings on to the table. What I predict is MOAB, the mother of all bills. And it's coming. And it is going to be a debt ceiling. It is going to be the government's annual budget. It's going to be health care reform, and it's going to have some infrastructure in it, and it will obviate the need for the 50 vote, or the 51 vote majority. It will operate with 60 because if you don't do it, the government stays shut until enough recalcitrant Democrats come along, maybe they get a little something, but that happens sometime in October.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: Congressman, there's this bill seems to have -- there're these goodies that keep coming. These multi -- I heard a $45 billion goody for someone, a $20 billion goody for another, a billion dollar goody for an Alaskan senator. This is part of the problem with D.C., right?

utterances.speaker: KUCINICH
utterances.utterance: When are the American people going to get the goodies in terms of adequate health care, insurance policies they can afford, get rid of the high deductibles. Look, health care is a major economic concern, but it also reflects what kind of a nation we are. I mean, this is a nation, we're United States, we must be united for our people's health and because that's wealth. And we need to think about how the insurance companies are making money not providing health care. And one thing I'd like to inject into this discussion that's never been brought up before in any of the debates, each one of us has a responsibility for our own health to an extent. And if we encourage personal responsibility, if we encourage prevention as part of it, we can lower health care costs. We can also make it possible to have a system where everyone is covered in America. That's what I stand for. I've written a legislation as a member of congress, Medicare for all. But Horace, I don't know that congress can slip this present bill into an overall budget bill because if they do, they'll shut down the government.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.utterance: Oh, it's going to shut down. That's part of the problem is if they don't get the 50 votes here, it's not going to pass. And then they're going to have the problem of what do you do to get those unhappy conservatives on board with the budget, with the debt ceiling, those people are not going to be satisfied with just giving a rubber-stamp to let things go as normal.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: I'm sorry. I want to bring in Kat in because that sounds terrible to me.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: That sounds terrible not only from a personal standpoint from an American citizen. It sounds terrible from a Republican standpoint that when you shut down the government, they tried it before -- it didn't work out so well. It was really, really bad for them.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Absolutely. And when we talk about health care, I know you and I are in complete agreement on this issue that this bill is a bad bill. It - - I mean, is Paul Ryan a conservative or is he not actually conservative? Are a lot of these GOP congressmen actually conservatives? And if they say they are, what does that mean? Because I never thought conservative meant $200 billion bailout to insurance companies. I just simply didn't.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.utterance: Because the bigger the bailout, the fewer the number of votes for people who believe in liberty and limited government are going to be there.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: Mo, I write a book called, The Swamp, and I take shot of people on both sides of the aisle. One of my problems with this bill is I'm questioning leadership on the Republican side on both the house and senate. You know, they didn't do the things that Congressman Kucinich says lowering the cost of health care. They're just playing around the edges. It feels a lot like Obamacare. That feels a lot like the swamp to me.

utterances.speaker: ELLEITHEE
utterances.utterance: Well, I don't know a lot of Democrats that would say this feels like Obamacare, right. But I do think that you're right, right? One of the things I learned a long time ago is when my opponents are making a case for me, I should just shut up. And you guys are making the case very effectively that this bill isn't doing what it says it's supposed to do. And that's why you're seeing conservative members of congress and moderate Republicans members of congress at each other throat's here. It's not lowering the cost of health care. For a lot of people, it is going to decrease access as projected right now under the current law. It is a no- win situation for anybody.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: Do you know who wins? The health care lobby. The health care -- and health care lobby. And maybe that's why the real issues have never been addressed yet on both sides.

utterances.speaker: KUCINICH
utterances.utterance: You're right on that, absolutely.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: I agree.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: We're going to leave it right there. Next up, a federal judge, yet again, weakens President Trump's travel ban. Can the judicial activism be stopped? Stay with us.

utterances.speaker: ELLEITHEE
utterances.utterance: A federal judge in Hawaii leveling a new hit on President Trump's travel ban against six Muslim majority countries. In his ruling, U.S. district judge, Derek Watson, has widely expanded the types of family members from those six countries that must be exempt from the ban, now to include grandparents, grandchildren, brothers-in-law, sisters-in-law, aunt, uncles, nieces, nephews, and cousins, of people in the U.S. The Justice Department announcing this afternoon that it will appeal the ruling. Horace, let me start with you. What's wrong with -- I mean, my grandparents, you know, my cousins, my uncles and aunts, are they family?

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.utterance: If Judge Watson were sitting in my class, we'd have to call him in afterward for some special remedial attention. Here's the fact. The policy that a judge is supposed to enforce is not about, what's a good idea, what's a kind way to operate, but what in fact is the law. And he is supposed to do what traditionally judges do is they give deference to the agency's interpretation of the law. And what is going to happen is either the ninth circuit or the Supreme Court are going to summarily, by summarily I mean with about nine days or less, overturn this decision. We've seen this kind of behavior before. I remember when there was a death penalty case and California was -- excuse me, the ninth circuit just didn't want to allow a death penalty to take place in the circuit. And they kept coming up with excuse after excuse after excuse. Finally, the Supreme Court said there will be no more appeals. That was dangerous.

utterances.speaker: ELLEITHEE
utterances.utterance: Congressman, let me ask you this. Let's flip that argument around, though, right? I mean, one could argue that the Trump administration's initial ruling was a huge overreach by the executive branch to define family, right?

utterances.speaker: KUCINICH
utterances.utterance: Actually, it was an overreach with respect to the constitution bringing up a religious text. But let's go beyond that. If you profess family values, that means families are valued. And if a grandfather, grandmother can't see their grandchildren, what's this about? I mean, what's happening to America?

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.utterance: But that's a policy point. That is not a legal question.

utterances.speaker: KUCINICH
utterances.utterance: It's about the heart.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.utterance: Yes. I don't want radicals on the court exercising what their heart dictates. What happens if they have the opposite view that you shouldn't be with your family? But they get to say, the president has set, judges go with what their own hearts are. We absolutely have to be constrained by the law.

utterances.speaker: KUCINICH
utterances.utterance: You know I wear this constitution in a vest pocket over my heart. The heart and the constitution have to be connected. You can't have.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: Do you know what else needs to be in there? The brain. You have to add the brain.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: That's what the court is doing. The court is 100 percent right, 9th Circuit. Look, this doesn't have to be a nice bill, a ban. It doesn't have to be good. It doesn't even have to be effective. It just has to be constitutional.

utterances.speaker: ELLEITHEE
utterances.utterance: That's correct.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: And the Supreme Court deemed it constitutional. So they can try and pick it apart piece by piece, but once they get to a certain point.

utterances.speaker: ELLEITHEE
utterances.utterance: But again, where...

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: ... this...

utterances.speaker: KUCINICH
utterances.utterance: Looked, it start out with constitutional problems, OK? And I would just invite you to look at the topic of heart-centered intelligence. There's always a neural connection between the heart and the brain.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: We all knew that this would be a little bit ambiguous, what does and does not designate a close relative or close family. I -- the travel ban, I see as security theater. I don't think it's going to -- I don't feel any safer because of it. However, it's constitutional. The president does have the authority to do these things. And what the court's doing here, I believe, is judicial activism.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.utterance: It is.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: That's what you just said. The ban isn't supposed to make -- the ban itself isn't supposed to keep dangerous people out and make you safer. The ban was supposed to be, let's take a breath, let's vet. Let's see if our systems are -- if they're working well enough. Slow down immigration until we find out if we're safe and what we need to fix. That was -- there was a big difference.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: I understand. I would actually like to hear a lot more how that's going and whether those are actually being reviewed.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: But if we're talking -- if we're talking about whether or not this is constitutional...

utterances.speaker: ELLEITHEE
utterances.utterance: We've got to move on.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: ... clearly, this is judicial activism.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: Hold on, wait, wait, wait.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.utterance: I worked in a government agency. You don't have double of people to both do the vetting and make sure the system works properly and actual implantation. And since the ban went into effect, the implementation has been going forward. There aren't the people around to now vet the system, just as you described.

utterances.speaker: ELLEITHEE
utterances.utterance: Well, this topic isn't going anywhere any time soon. Coming up, it's time to wake up, America. Eric will sound off on the Trump administration's Sebastian Gorka and his recent showdowns with the mainstream media. Next.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: Welcome back to "The Fox News Specialists." Our specialists today are Dennis Kucinich and Horace Cooper. Welcome, both of you guys. Let's continue the conversation. It's time to wake up, America. What a week it's been in the liberal wilderness that is the mainstream media. I really think I stumbled on the reason these journalists keep getting duped by their own anxious anticipation to take down Trump. They just can't believe how they got it all wrong. Hillary was going to win, and the wildly biased liberal media was ready to heap adoration on their golden girl for years to come. Who can forget these scene from the 2015 election -- from 2015, I'm sorry -- where the liberal media was so excited for just a glimpse of their candidate's Scooby-Doo van they almost trampled each other for a peek. Watch.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: You can see the media running behind me here to chase the Scooby van. She's going around to the back.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Wow.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: And we'll see her -- we'll see her very soon.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: The guy in the orange pants is pretty quick. Alex, I mean, I'm looking at these people. Wow. All right. Orange Pants, he's really outnumbered now.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: I think that's Jake Tapper in the orange pants. I'm not sure. Isn't that precious? And then nine months after her loss, the media still can't get over it.

utterances.speaker: Case in point
utterances.utterance: Wednesday night, Anderson Cooper took an on-air beating in the debate with Sebastian Gorka. He should've left it right there. Instead, Cooper later brought in a stage filled of supporters to analyze the interview. Anderson's friends tried to convince him and his audience that it wasn't such a bad beating after all that Gorka had just administered. So how did Anderson Cooper respond to all the felicitation?

utterances.speaker: PAUL BEGALA, CNN POLITICAL CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.utterance: It's because he gives interviews like that, the way Donald Trump does.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON COOPER, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.utterance: It's like Don Rickles. It's like the Hungarian Don Rickles. I don't worry too much about it. But I just find it interesting that he doesn't answer questions.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: Anderson, Anderson, Anderson. Cheap shot at Gorka using his nationality as a joke. That's so not tolerant of you. Now, if I did that joke about someone's ethnic background, your pals in the liberal media would be calling for my head. Good thing we conservatives, Sebastian Gorka included, can laugh at your jokes. Speaking of funny, though, couldn't pass the opportunity to remind you all of that election night in May for the special election in Georgia 6, this picture could be titled "#notwinning." They say a picture speaks a thousand words. Oh, boy, does it ever. Now Congressman, look at the long faces on there. So what do you think about this? I mean, do you think they keep pulling these Russia stories after Russia stories, they completely missed the Trump win?

utterances.speaker: KUCINICH
utterances.utterance: Well, yes. I mean, there are people who are not over the 2016 election.

utterances.speaker: And I think it's important for the Democrats to reorganize and move forward with an agenda that will attract the attention of the American people and win their sentiments on practical matters
utterances.utterance: Economy, health care, education, retirement security, peace. Those are things that people are concerned about. But you know, the stuff that's going on in the media, though, there's a lot of hyper partisanship that's not good for the country. And as far as Mr. Gorka being the Hungarian Don Rickles, I think that we ought to be sensitive to it being taken as a slight to the Hungarian community, even though I knew Don Rickles; he was a wonderful comic. So let's thank the Hungarian people for their contribution to America. (SPEAKING FOREIGN LANGUAGE)

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: Very, very good. Nice -- nicely done, Congressman. Horace, your thoughts on what the media, their minds are blown that Donald Trump is president right now. But I agree with the congressmen. As long as the Democrats keep focusing on Trump and Russia, they're never going to come up with an agenda that's going to win in 2018.

utterances.speaker: H. COOPER
utterances.utterance: So it's a curious business model. This network came about, because people recognized that the majority of the American people -- and as a kid, myself, I'm one of those -- who said, "We're not being well served with a fair and balanced news network." And it appeared, and suddenly, swarms of people -- and at one point, it became so large that it was competing with ESPN and all these others. Here's what I believe is happening.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: No, we win.

utterances.speaker: H. COOPER
utterances.utterance: Not competing. No, win.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: Winning.

utterances.speaker: H. COOPER
utterances.utterance: CNN says, "Well, I know what I'm going to do. I'm going to get that smaller, much smaller group, a minority of people who have a whole different idea about America, and they wish Hillary had won. And we'll just get them to watch us. And it could actually increase our rating by 20 percent, or 30 percent." They're never going to get a majority of the American people. And in fact, they're alienating the overwhelming majority of the public. But it's a business model that they think is worth it. It would be far better to go after all of America. And you'll see how positive that could be.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: Kat, your thoughts on the mainstream -- do they have Trump Derangement Syndrome?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: I think that certain people do. I just don't know why I'm not allowed to care like just kind of. To think that maybe there's something there a little bit, but it's not the only thing we should be talking about. I feel like there's one side that says this is a nothing burger, and it's a, you know, deep-state liberal media thing. And then another thing says, for sure, Trump should be impeached.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: Treason. Treason.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Treason. Putin. I just am not ready to put a tinfoil hat on, on either side right now. I'm just -- I'm not trying to be an FBI agent/psychic.

utterances.speaker: H. COOPER
utterances.utterance: Let me -- let me make a quick point.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: I'm saying, "Hey, there are certain questions I have. Let's wait and see it play out. And can we talk about some other stuff and, you know, also this, but some other stuff, too?"

utterances.speaker: H. COOPER
utterances.utterance: Quick point.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: Go ahead.

utterances.speaker: H. COOPER
utterances.utterance: Malaysia. When the plane crashed, it was a real story. It just didn't need to get 23 hours out of the day. This is the same thing.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: So you're saying -- Horace is saying maybe Trump is CNN's new Malaysia?

utterances.speaker: ELLEITHEE
utterances.utterance: Well, the thing is, Malaysia wasn't ideological. It wasn't political. It was sensational. Right? Look, I think we are in a war here between -- between politicians of both parties and the media. Right? Go back 20 years. It's not like the media went easy on questions like the Lewinsky scandal or Whitewater. That was wall-to-wall coverage. The Clinton White House felt like it was in a bunker back during those days. Now you've got this White House saying, "Why aren't you covering anything else?" The media is saying, "Well, because the president just tweeted about this..."

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: President Obama says -- leans over to Dmitry Medvedev and says, "After the election -- tell Putin after the election, I'll have more leeway to do things." And that -- that was ignored by the media.

utterances.speaker: ELLEITHEE
utterances.utterance: Do you know how I know about that? Because I saw it on the media. Every network.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: Here, here. You saw it here.

utterances.speaker: ELLEITHEE
utterances.utterance: Well, I don't remember which one I was watching that day, but I know they all covered it. They all covered it, Eric.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: They aren't covering it wall-to-wall the way they're covering everything that Trump ever -- every person that Trump meets is, you know, somehow colluding with him.

utterances.speaker: ELLEITHEE
utterances.utterance: The reality is both parties feel under siege by the media, and they're feeding the ongoing battle.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: We're going to leave it right there. Straight ahead, it's "Kat on the Street." New York City is becoming more and more of stress-ridden mess. So why are so many tourists still flocking here? We all want to know. But Kat finds out, next.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: It's been said that New York is the greatest city in the world. For the life of me, I can't understand why. Forbes ranks New York as the second most stressful city in America. And a new study says it's the third worst-run city in the country. Despite it all, more than 60 million tourists visit the Big Apple for vacation. So I headed over to the tourist mecca, Times Square, to find out why they were there on purpose.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: So you guys are tourists?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Yes, we are.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Meaning you came to New York City for vacation?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Yes, we did.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Where are you from?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Atlanta, Georgia.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: From Kansas.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: We're from Canada.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: And you came to New York City to relax?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Please help me. Any tips for me in terms of how to relax in New York? Have you figured that out?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: I mean, I guess we're going to try to figure it out. I'm sure you've been here longer than we have.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: We've been here for about three hours.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Been here for three hours?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Three hours.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: You've probably aged ten years, and you just don't know it yet. Do you feel very relaxed right now?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: My wife is a little tense.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: I am a little tense all the time. That's just how it is.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: We're going to Niagara Falls after this, and she's ready to leave now.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: So you are in Times Square on purpose?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Absolutely. No other place in the world like it.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Well, that's true.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: The planning was to go to Asbury Park, and I thought, well, my goodness, we can't come all the way over here and not see the city.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Beach condo sounds like vacation. New York? It's like if a panic attack were a city. So what's been your favorite thing so far to see?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: The Times Square is very nice. And the Central Park as well.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Central Park, vacation vibes. Times Square more like a vibe to me.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Yes, it is. It is.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: We were just talking about that. People come here to get energized.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: What energizes you in the city?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: It's just the excitement. The atmosphere.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: The atmosphere never stops. You can smell it right now. Have you taken the subway yet?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: No, I don't think we're going to do that.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: You seem very relaxed. How do you say so chill in New York City?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: A lot of wine. I'm just kidding.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: That's what I do. What have you done that's been so relaxing?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: We took the ferry to Staten Island.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: The Staten Island ferry is relaxing. This is all very incredible information.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: It's actually pretty stressful. It's a really big cultural shock. Very different from anything I'm used to seeing.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: You came from New York City from Spain for a vacation. Do you feel relaxed right now?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Sometimes I just, you know, stay under my bed, and you know, just stay there and I don't leave. I never felt like the words "vacation" and "New York City" belonged in the same sentence.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: I'm a big theater nerd. So, like, this is where the best theater is. So for me, like, doing that and seeing something new is a vacation.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Wow, that's like -- I do see something new every day here. Not always good stuff, though. You look very relaxed right now. Are you relaxing in New York?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Sure.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: That's a very relaxed answer. He didn't even care I was asking the question. That's amazing. I need more of this attitude. Can we talk later?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: We go, like, rat watching in the subway system.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: You go rat watching in the subways?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Yes, we do.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: So I should be looking at the rats as my friends/a potential evening plan. So maybe New York is kind of awesome. I just need to embrace it. Also, if anybody wants to go rat watching with me in the subway later, I'd be willing to give it a try.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Any takers? Rat watching?

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: No. Apparently, it's very common, though. Look, Times Square is iconic. People come to see all the lights and everything. And Broadway, that young lady said she comes to Broadway.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: It's the best Broadway -- it's the best theater on the planet. But did you ever notice, like, all these post-apocalyptic movies, like, the world is ending, Times Square is still kicking?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: Like, everyone meets in Times Square and they survive?

utterances.speaker: ELLEITHEE
utterances.utterance: They could make a (UNINTELLIGIBLE) of tourism, right?

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: ELLEITHEE
utterances.utterance: Look, the most stressful thing about -- I live in D.C. Not exactly the most relaxed city in the world.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: ELLEITHEE
utterances.utterance: The most stressful thing about New York is getting here for me. To the powers that be, if you can fix LaGuardia Airport, please! Do that! Right? But you know, look, I love this piece. I love these real Americans from all over the country, from all over the world, who just are excited to, like, be in New York and -- you come here to see things you will not see anywhere else.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: That is true. You want to weigh in?

utterances.speaker: KUCINICH
utterances.utterance: Look, I'm from Cleveland.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: KUCINICH
utterances.utterance: And next to Cleveland, New York is the greatest.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Cleveland is wonderful!

utterances.speaker: H. COOPER
utterances.utterance: I call that damning but faint praise.

utterances.speaker: KUCINICH
utterances.utterance: Oh, no, no, no. Cleveland is the greatest. But here...

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: Not in baseball, though.

utterances.speaker: KUCINICH
utterances.utterance: Hey!

utterances.speaker: H. COOPER
utterances.utterance: Oh!

utterances.speaker: KUCINICH
utterances.utterance: First in American League and first in the hearts of the people. But energy, drama, excitement in the streets here. This -- there's a pulsation here. This town is alive! And so you've got to celebrate it.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: I agree. I love living here. It's very alive, very awake. But sometimes I want to take a nap. You know what I mean.

utterances.speaker: KUCINICH
utterances.utterance: Oh, come on.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: It's really, really hard.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: Don't take one on the subway.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Yes, don't do that.

utterances.speaker: H. COOPER
utterances.utterance: Apparently not. According to what I've seen on "Drudge," it's not a good idea.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Not a good idea. Well, if New York stresses you out too much, Nevada could be your cup of tea to mellow out. Recreational weed because legal there two weeks ago. There's just one problem. Booming sales have now led to a statewide shortage. Stocks are so plum dry the state's Republican governor has been forced to step in and push emergency regulations to boost the number of distributors. You know, they're talking about million-dollar tax revenue here. Excuse me...

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: Many, yes.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Yes, many millions, up to 100 million in tax revenue. So yes, they should probably get it together.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: Listen, I'm on board. Legalize it, or definitely decriminalize it across the country and legalize it. The numbers you point out, massive tax revenue to the state, and they all need it.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Yes, absolutely.

utterances.speaker: H. COOPER
utterances.utterance: I'm not on board on the pot legalization train. You know, if Friday night comes along and you need something, what's wrong with a little Grey Goose that you can get at the corner? Why do you need to take this opportunity that really comes with a whole host of other baggage?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: I prefer vodka, personally. I would shoot -- yes, I'm not really a weed gal, but some people are; and that's their choice. And that should be their ability to get it legally if they want.

utterances.speaker: KUCINICH
utterances.utterance: I don't smoke. I don't drink. And I don't care if marijuana is legal.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KUCINICH
utterances.utterance: And if people can make revenue out of it, they did the same thing with alcohol.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: A hundred million is what they're saying in tax revenue, and why not? And if people, they can -- Nevada, they can probably get it anyways. They're just doing it legally, better, safer, tax revenue. Everybody is happy. Everybody should be a fan. All right. When he return -- I bet you some people won't be -- but we special back with our specialists, Dennis Kucinich and Horace Cooper. Come back.

utterances.speaker: ELLEITHEE
utterances.utterance: Time to "Circle Back" with our specialists, Dennis Kucinich and Horace Cooper. Congressman, you -- you're a Democrat. You were known to be a very liberal Democrat. But you recently slammed the Democratic Party for destroying the party as the party -- the opposition party, as effective opposition. What advice would you give to Democrats who want to make a contrast with this administration to be more effective?

utterances.speaker: KUCINICH
utterances.utterance: If you want to challenge Donald Trump, fine. But offer real alternatives. I think that, you know, the Democrats, in my view, shouldn't be locked into defending Obamacare but should be offering a real health care proposal: single-payer, Medicare for all. The Democrats ought to stand for peace, instead of voting for continually funding wars. The Democrats ought to stand for jobs for all. That goes in with Mr. Trump's infrastructure program. The Democrats ought to stand for education for all. There's 32 million Americans that are -- adults, who are -- who are illiterate. We've got to do something about lifting up the country.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: Horace, my question is for you. You say you're a political forecaster. What's the political weather looks like next week? Heavy rain, Russia, what have we got?

utterances.speaker: H. COOPER
utterances.utterance: A Trump tweet.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.utterance: A Trump tweet, all right. That's probably 100 percent accurate.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: Just a few more seconds right now. Go to my Twitter, take a look at the picture I posted of the congressman and I. We squared up. I said we're going to battle some liberals. You've got some good style; you've got some good form there, Congressman. A fighter?

utterances.speaker: KUCINICH
utterances.utterance: I am, a lot of practice. Actually, I'm a lover, not a fighter. I believe in peace, not war. And I love New York.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: He's a blackbelt. He told me. You said -- he said, "Legally, I have to warn you. I'm a black belt."

utterances.speaker: KUCINICH
utterances.utterance: No, no, I said martial artist. But that was...

utterances.speaker: H. COOPER
utterances.utterance: (UNINTELLIGIBLE) some jets there. But give war a chance!

utterances.speaker: KUCINICH
utterances.utterance: It's been given a chance.

utterances.speaker: ELLEITHEE
utterances.utterance: All right, thank you. Thank you to our "Fox News Specialists" today, Dennis Kucinich and Horace Cooper. And my thanks to everyone at Fox and "The Specialists" here for letting me sit in for Eboni K. Williams today. We thank you all for watching. Remember, 5 p.m. will never be the same. "Special Report" is next.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.utterance: Weekend!
